text: What everyone says here is great. Just wanted to chime in that yes I have and I've actually had a much easier time getting editors to understand voice, tone, etc. than freelance writers. Every one I've worked with has had their own set of pricing structures that they presented to us, we didn't set the pricing.

elements.text: What everyone says here is great. Just wanted to chime in that yes I have and I've actually had a much easier time getting editors to understand voice, tone, etc. than freelance writers. Every one I've worked with has had their own set of pricing structures that they presented to us, we didn't set the pricing.

text: All of the editors I've used have been members of the Editorial Freelancers Association and American Copy Editors Society (which I'm also a member of). It might be worth starting with either of those organizations to find recommendations.

elements.text: All of the editors I've used have been members of the Editorial Freelancers Association and American Copy Editors Society (which I'm also a member of). It might be worth starting with either of those organizations to find recommendations.

text: This is super tactical, but I've hired editors to proofread things first, and found that helps them get a sense of our voice and tone and target market over time. When I start to notice them picking up more voice/tone things in their edits, I start assigning them more copyediting/substantive editing tasks. I generally do a QA for subject matter knowledge and write the briefs myself (caveat: I'm in-house, so that probably makes it easier!).

text:
I really like the build that you’re describing <@UUVC10WAY>, this seems similar to <@UJDPMTREY>’s having a more general editor taking the first look and then an SME editor.

Also <@U01BLESEU1E> great rec on ACES! My team just did their editing course based on a recommendation from this group. I didn’t realize I could also source through them for this type of role. Thank you!
